review_title: Great Spot to Start Your Career
pros:
-The rotational aspect of the program is great in that you can experience 4 very different roles over the course of 2 years, which is great for trying to understand a company as large as Cisco. The variety of roles is clearly a plus as you are able to preference which areas interest you as you move throughout your time in the program.
-Generally, the expectations from your teams are within reason but provide a challenge at least in my experience. Learning is encouraged and mistakes are seen as an opportunity to grow rather than a reason for criticism.
-The program itself feels like a family of sorts that you can relate with people in the same boat as yourself early in career. This makes for a great support system and provides an automatic resource for general questions.
cons:
-Sometimes timing of role responsibilities and additional program expectations can overlap which can create a challenge; however, these are chances to exercise time management.
-Transitions can be a little tricky to manage due to turnover of roles (some new ones can be added and others) so some processes aren't as clearly defined. Generally business partners are understanding though and there's always help to get you up to speed.

review_title: Great Place to Work and Impact Your Community
job_title: Security technical solutions architect in Denver, CO
pros:
- There is always something new to learn and keep things interesting
- There are plenty of opportunities to move within the company
- Truly care about the individual especially during difficult personal times. And I've seen time and again Senior Execs step in and help.
- Great benefits especially Medical for my and my families needs
- full week of community service beyond your PTO and everyone is encouraged to find someway to give back
- strong Senior Exec leadership especially during tough times
cons:
- During annual 'Limited Restructures', it's not about being a rock star or not, it's your position that is eliminated including whole teams
- Tight weekly commits can cause stress within teams depending on management
- Marketing has continued to overpromise or oversell, Cisco didn't use to sell on roadmaps
- dilution of culture. when I first started you could call anyone from John Chambers down and you would get a response. Now, it's not uncommon for someone to not respond unless you cc: their manager and yours.

job_title: Senior Communications Manager in San Jose, CA
pros: Smart people, flexibility to work from home, some interesting business areas, lots of potential.
cons: Strong performers carry the load of others, leaders don’t enforce discipline and adherence to project timelines, managers are afraid to take action to improve conditions for high performers and make excuses for those who underperform. Senior staff is complacent and in denial about attrition issues and other matters impeding growth. The company has grown stale, inefficient and lost it’s edge. And there is no genuine interest in hearing the truth from employees. Your exit survey is not anonymous. That’s telling. That says everything about the company’s interest in improving conditions for employees.

pros:
Good starting point for everyone, who wants to "boost up" technical skills in a short period of time at the cost of mental health. 1-2 years maximum for TAC/HTTS and probably PS, 2-3 years for CSS. Everything, that is more than that is fraught with stagnation and distress.

You will have a chance to work with the best minds in the industry... if you find them. Cisco have talents indeed, but their rotation rate is dismaying.
cons: Management... Micro-management is everywhere. It is propagated and inflicted from from top to bottom and you can do literally nothing with that. Words like "good job", "keep stunning results", "here to help" mean nothing here for "Senior Managers"... Gab fest.

review_title: Great experience that sadly fell apart
job_title: Software Engineer III in San Francisco, CA
pros: Cisco was great because I joined a team that was highly motivated and out to build something new. I worked out of the Meraki office and really liked all of my co-workers in the building and the culture that was built there. We initially had really good dynamic, and for a period of time I really enjoyed my day to day. Over time, we had a series of leadership changes, acquisitions, and after nearly a dozen manager changes in a few short years and an exodus of talent, my team became a shell of what it formerly was. I had great experiences finding other ways to involve myself in the Cisco community that led to a lot of amazing new connections and opportunities that I will forever be grateful for. Cisco has abundant opportunities outside of your immediate org if you are motivated and ask to be involved. There were a lot of amazing upsides to Cisco, but my immediate BU was horribly mismanaged.
cons:
Unreasonable amounts of pager duty (I was a SWE and on PD 12h a day for over 100 days of the year)
Poor upper level management of the BU caused an exodus of talent
Too many manager changes in too short of time

review_title: Stable job, slow advancement, understaffed, heavily political
job_title: Software Engineer II in San Jose, CA
pros: Reasonable pay, comfortable, stable, somewhat flexible work times, good benefits, later work time start, standard 20 days PTO.
cons:
Few top down directives, teams instead are largely independent, leads to teams fighting internally to achieve their own objectives rather than for benefit of Cisco. 
Heavily political.
(pre pandemic) Officially: working from home is allowed, Unofficially: working from home generally frowned upon, need to be in office unless sick or have important errand.
Officially: switching jobs within the company is allowed and encouraged. Unofficially managers get really petty when this happens and usually drops your bonus to minimum.
Technology and tools is generally behind the curve, huge legacy issues prevent investment in reworking.
Advancement/pay raises usually very limited, however not for lack of desire by direct managers.
Company culture is pretty bland, team cultures vary.
No dedicated sick time

review_title: CSAP Program Amsterdam - Sales Engineering Traineeship at Cisco
pros:
Great early in career kickstart for bachelor and master graduate students.
Four industry wide recognized certificates (CCNA, DevNet Associate, CCNP, Devnet Professional). 
Possibility to network with executive leaders within the company as well as building your own network with the other CSAPers.
It is definitely possible to join without prior experience in IT/Networking. Technical and sales bootcamp to learn everything about Cisco's portfolio, sales techniques and more.
The Cisco Culture is great, very welcoming to associates. You are highly encouraged to get to know people, ask questions and find your strengths.
cons:
Management and the curriculum do expect a lot from the associates, extra hours are expected and not compensated.
The Work From Home format does work quite well, but makes it harder to draw clear boundaries between leisure time and working hours.

review_title: Great culture and teamwork with improvement for employee retention
job_title: IT Engineer in Research Triangle Park, NC
pros:
Always has a group of senior IT engineers and architects to ask questions to. They were always easy to approach and happy to answer questions and provide guidance (not sure if this is luck of the draw with their personalities, or if it is company/organization culture quite honestly).
Most of the managers are great people who provide guidance and try to help you determine your career path and put you on projects you would enjoy and your skills align to (there is always a "bad apple" manager, but this is the exception).
cons: The IT side in particular seems to be following what I consider a negative trend in the industry of hiring contractors for specific projects with the skills needed, rather than training the full time employees they already have who have gotten the company to the successful state they are in. You won't get the best talent using primarily contractors and they will leave eventually. Then the company will lose their experience and knowledge after the project ends, when they could provide guidance towards a future project.

pros: Flexibility is key at Cisco, where a whopping 67% of employees can telecommute or work remotely, making it the most flexible workplace on the list.
cons: On campus, employees of the IT and networking tech company enjoy a host of perks, including fitness centers and bike paths, cafés and gourmet food trucks, childcare centers and mothers' rooms, and "fun funds" for team celebrations and team-building exercises.

review_title: Rewarding work, Good coworkers, Ridiculous upper management churn
pros: The work was technically challenging and my coworkers were a great group to work. The benefits were decent and bonus was nice. I was provided the tools needed.
cons: There is a ridiculous amount of churn at the SVP level . Had 4 SVP leaders in 32 months. Churn just below them the same. One VP lasted 2 months. No on the same page but the big bonus's stay the same. They also contradict each other. Our SVP said to focus on quality and a group meeting. The next week the group VP said focus on time to market not quality, the exact opposite. You tend to get siloed and management does not seem able to figure out get workers access to the numerous training programs or worse this lack of access is intentional. Tell your manager to figure out how to get access to "Chuck" bucks for training. Intergroup working relationships can be difficult probably due to the Cisco HR stacked ranking mechanism. People do not want to help out when integrating different products/functionality together. Definite ageism in labor reduction practices. Buy other companies then start killing the product even when still achieving 20% growth. I'm sure the tier 1 telco's are going to be happy about that.

pros:
I am part of the Cloud Security team within the overall Security Business unit at Cisco. 

The big pros (from the perspective of my team):
- An awesome startup-like culture where everyone is encouraged to take initiatives 
- No strict hierarchies followed - Hierarchies exist in designations, but in practice, any engineer can freely go and talk to a senior manager or director. 
- Hackathons twice a year - where everyone works on an innovation of their choice for 2 days. This is taken seriously by top management, and the most innovative ideas are recognized and rewarded. Even if you are not part of a winning team, its an amazing experience.
cons: Cisco is lagging competitors in some areas, which means there is tremendous pressure to catch up, and so a lot of work especially in recent times.

job_title: Marketing Manager in San Francisco, CA
pros:
Cisco has the most inspiring and ethical ELT I have ever seen at a company, with many women in leadership positions. It is truly progressive and has a warm and fuzzy feel, despite being such a large company. There are many different types of products, so depending on what you're looking for, you could find a global role or a more of a startup feel depending on the business unit.
Like any big company, the red tape can be frustrating, but I don't think the politics are that bad and it's not a cutthroat atmosphere at all.
cons: Unfortunately Cisco doesn't pay well and it's hard to get a decent raise. Some of the products do very well and others struggle to keep up with single product/pure play competitors who have more dedicated resources.

review_title: Superior Work Life Balance, Frustrating Bureaucracy
job_title: Data Scientist in San Jose, CA
pros: Cisco has always had female leadership presence and because of that, the company takes work life balance very seriously. Also, because they invented telecommuting, that lifestyle is built into their DNA. Almost everyone I worked with was excellent. When we got our red tape out of the way, we did a lot of cool stuff.
cons:
The company is gigantic. This primarily manifests itself in 2 ways: Layoffs and Bureaucratic Slowdown.

Cisco pretty much has a standard policy of cutting 10% of the workforce every, single, year. A lot times the layoffs make ZERO sense at all, and people often get rehired at higher salaries. It's almost a Silicon Valley tradition to be laid off off from Cisco at some point in your career.

From a software/Data Science perspective, the red tape primarily shows itself in data access. Finding the right data steward and actually completing data permissions is a frustrating and circuitous process. But, on the other hand, red tape slows things down so much it's pretty rare to get overwhelmed.

review_title: good life work balance company for minority but too many layoff and politics
job_title: Software Engineer in San Jose, CA
pros:
The working environment is pretty relax and easy in the legacy and matured product BU.
You don't need to work more than 6 hours a day because most of the work are pretty routine.
Allow work remotely from home and flexible working hours.
Training and connection in women in tech helps you to move up fast.
A great place for female and Indian. You feel like home.
A lot of loyal customers and doesn't matter how far we are behind the competitors.
cons:
Layoff happens across BU and take place every year.
Big layoff every 4 years.
Company hierarchy is crazy. My report chain is me -> manager -> director -> VP -> VP -> VP -> SVP -> EVP -> CEO. It doesn't make sense to have so many VPs.
Many new products are not generating revenue.
Cloud do impact the hardware business which is Cisco bread and butter.
There are too many similar products in the company and fighting with each other .
Collaboration between different BU are not working well due to politics.

pros: Great portfolio and fantastic channel and partner ecosystem
cons: Market transition to cloud and SW impacting Business model and traditional hw business

pros: The campus is great with facilities like cafeterias and gyms and other areas for the employees to hangout during the day.
cons:
Unprofessional and incompetent management in CMS India. They like to call themselves "leadership" but clearly they don't have any leadership qualities. 
If anything they lead the project into the ground. The project I was working in went under CAP but the so called "Leaders" still got promoted. 
Engineers with work experience from 2-5 years were not given opportunity to grow but the management hired freshers and gave them more salary than experienced individuals. 
Tenured engineers who worked from the start of the project were neglected and new people with zero technical knowledge were hired as "Incident Manager". 
They hired someone as blue badge just for making roster. If the info is correct he got the job because he was OM's old roommate.
Discrimination between blue and red badge employees is very common even though they both work equally in the team.

If Cisco really wants to improve upon the teams performance and client satisfaction they should really launch an internal investigation in the CMS India to find out why the client is unhappy and how the whole project went under CAP and the managers still got promoted to IMs to OMs and also Global heads. 
Meanwhile most of the actual L2 and L3 engineers are suffering from depression and have left the job and/or planning to leave.

review_title: Such a great place to work!
job_title: Collaboration Customer Success Manager in Research Triangle Park, NC
pros:
-Extremely supportive coworkers (the most helpful people I know)
-The benefits are amazing - not just 401K/PTO/Health Insurance, but Cisco has so many continued learning events and resources, 5 days VTO (volunteer time off) to give back, employee resource organizations to get involved with, on site gym (with awesome classes) and healthcare facilities, plus a lot of on-site events to promote cross-collaboration with other groups. 
- The pay is amazing.
- Very communicative and transparent with all changes/considerations. We have monthly All-Hands via Cisco TV where our CEO and much of the C-Suite are updating us on the latest happenings in the company.
- Very supportive leadership in ensuring you are set up for success and continually helping you to identify and plan for future roles you may want to take on.
cons:
- The commute/traffic to RTP.
- Like many large companies, there are a lot of old tools, processes, and systems that you have to use to do your job. They are working hard to consolidate them though! 
- Again, with many other large companies, lay offs can happen (but Cisco did put on an internal career fair the last time for those being displaced to try and refill open positions based on skillsets of those that were impacted.)

pros:
- A lot of great people that are open, willing to help and brilliant.
- Work from home (even before covid)
cons:
I always wanted to work for Cisco, but over the past several years I've seen a decline in culture and quality. 

- Complicated products! Look at how complicated SDA is, look at how complex our "multi-domain" strategy is. 
- Awful product quality. It's sad that we have to vet out our products for our customers in order to avoid trainwrecks (e.g. When FTD was released, SDA right now, ISA before 2.0)
- Silo'd. We talk about how we offer an end-to-end solution, but when it comes to sales, deployment, and even post-sales support everything is extremely silo'd. Have a multi-architectures solution? Good luck! 
- No career growth opportunities unless you move. Extremely difficult to get a grade bump or raise.
- Pay is no longer competitive compared to other big vendors. 
- YEARLY layoffs! Sometimes twice a year.

review_title: Great place to start and end your career
job_title: Program Manager in San Jose, CA
pros: Pay is decent but not as high as other tech companies around the area. 401k matching, fairly good health benefits, WFH and working remotely are available to most employees, but it depends on your team and manager. Its a great place to start your career but most early in career people leave to other tech companies after 2-3 years. Cisco doesn't do a good job of retaining some of their top talent. This is a perfect company for those with a family and like a lot flexibility. Most departments are pretty relaxed and hardly ever hit 40 hours of work a week
cons:
Overall there aren't too many cons. The two biggest issues I see is a lack of merit increase each year. Some people can stay at their same salary for 5 years. Promotions are fairly hard to get if you don't play politics. Saw a lot great talent leave when they didn't get recognized. 

The only other major con is upper management. There are too many directors and senior leaders that care more about their bonus and don't focus on the bigger picture of doing whats best for the company.

job_title: Data Scientist in San Jose, CA
pros:
1. Intellectually curious, driven and hard-working people (if you know where to look)

2. Everybody talks about this and this is in-part true: balancing life with professional obligations is easier than in certain sectors of the industry

3. Interesting projects in the security domain. For example, if you are interested in applying theory from high-dimensional statistics, signal processing, stochastic processes, causal inference and survival analysis there are many novel projects that you can get involved in.
cons:
As a data scientist here are some observations:

1. Bureaucracy and red tape for accessing data and understanding data - primarily because of disjoint business groups and over-reliance on data warehousing consultants in India (Tata etc.)

2. Actual implementation of solutions that use data is exceedingly difficult. Certain business units of Cisco are on various parts of the spectrum of ML Operations and data infrastructure. Thus, these same business units are on varying spectrums for data science integrations into their services and products. Consistently, however, technical resourcing for data science teams, competent leadership with experience in deploying models and product management for data products is a deficit that impedes impact.

3. Related to (2) - cultural changes and frequent reorganizations interrupt or disrupt continuity of development of data science projects or actual production implementation of solutions.

4. Lack of investment in data infrastructure. Cisco’s engineering and data scientist teams (sans the acquisitions) are still mired in “software development” mindsets. There is little understanding or awareness be senior management and technical leaders of the challenges or workflow of data science projects and challenges with hard data science problems. 

5. All of the above is not abetted by a culture of sales and feature factories for current products - both legacy and SaaS.

review_title: LIFT Program - Exceptional Leadership Development and Finance Training
job_title: Financial Analyst in San Jose, CA
pros: Cisco's LIFT program provides exceptional training and development opportunities in the program. Because you rotate to a new role every 6 months, you create a large network of highly skilled professionals over the two years in the program. The managers in the program are invested in your development and put in a significant amount of time to accelerate your career. In addition there is frequent exposure to executive leadership and several opportunities to lead initiatives and events. Cisco's culture is also very inclusive and gives back generously to the community. Benefits package is also great.
cons: Pay is average and you are hired into the LIFT program a grade below other entry level Financial Analysts at Cisco. LIFT program director controls compensation & bonus. Performance evaluations in the LIFT program are heavily weighted on presentation skills and training test scores from a 1 week training, and only partially on your role performance. If you score average in the training, you will receive an average bonus even if you have high ratings on your role performance.

pros: They did provide thorough training and were always very helpful with all the materials needed to succeed.
cons: Full Cisco benefits were not an options since I was employed through a contractor. No fast track to getting an contractor role for Cisco.

pros: One of the main reasons I love working at Cisco are the people and the environment we are surrounded with. Having a high-trust organization such as Cisco helps us avoid micro management and employees are getting most of their potential. Apart from work, we love to have fun and rest our minds from business thoughts. In one of our Global Team meetings we had Chris Martin from Coldplay join us and play a few songs. How cool is that? As a big successful corporation we have a lot of job benefits, newest technology and always moving forward!
cons: Being a part of such big organization means that change is constant and it is something that we need to adapt as the world and priorities are constantly changing too. Nothing that worries me too much as we know this is the only way to stay ahead of the competition.
